P.title: Will the S&P 500 rise or fall more than 15% in a single day during the 2020s?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if before January 1st 2030 and after January 1st 2020, the S&P 500 moves by more than 15.0% from opening to closing price, in a single day

Q.title: Will the UK have a Labour Prime Minister on January 1, 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the UK Prime Minister on January 1, 2030 is a member of the Labour Party.
Otherwise, the question resolves negatively.
Show More

P_and_Q.title: Will the S&P 500 rise or fall more than 15% in a single day during the 2020s AND will the UK have a Labour Prime Minister on January 1, 2030?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if both of the following conditions are met: a.) before January 1st 2030 and after January 1st 2020, the S&P 500 moves by more than 15.0% from opening to closing price, in a single day AND b.) the UK Prime Minister on January 1, 2030 is a member of the Labour Party.
Otherwise, the question resolves negatively.

P.title: Will the S&P 500 rise or fall more than 15% in a single day during the 2020s?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if before January 1st 2030 and after January 1st 2020, the S&P 500 moves by more than 15.0% from opening to closing price, in a single day

metadata.background_info: The S&P 500 is often used as a benchmark for the performance of large-cap companies in the United States. On October 19, 1987 (so-called Black Monday), the S&P fell 20.47%, the largest movement in its history, which has yet to be surpassed. Generally, when the stock market makes a sudden move, it indicates that there has been some economic shock, such as when the S&P 500 fell 11.98% during the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic.

Q.title: Will the UK have a Labour Prime Minister on January 1, 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the UK Prime Minister on January 1, 2030 is a member of the Labour Party.
Otherwise, the question resolves negatively.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
Related Question on Metaculus:
Will the UK have a Conservative Prime Minister on January 1, 2030?
The Labour Party is a centre-left political party in the United Kingdom that has been described as an alliance of social democrats, democratic socialists and trade unionists. The party's platform emphasises greater state intervention, social justice and strengthening workers' rights. As of 2020, it was last in power from 1997 to 2010.

reasons: Economic policies of a Labour Prime Minister could influence global markets, including the S&P 500.
A significant political shift in the UK could lead to market volatility, potentially causing large movements in stock indices.
Investors might react to the UK's political landscape, affecting global investor sentiment and market behavior.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as political changes in the UK could impact global financial markets.

P.title: Will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
There is said to be an "AI Sputnik moment" if ANY of the following come true before 2050,
A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system. Upon the announcement, their stock price skyrockets by over 100% compared to its previous value within 7 days, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock price is likely a result of the AI development.
Show More

Q.title: Who will be elected to be US President in 2024? (Donald Trump)
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the person who wins the 2024 US presidential election, and No for all other options. This will be the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment.
This question is not limited to the individuals currently listed below; the question may resolve as No for all listed options, and options may be added later.
Show More

P_and_Q.title: Will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050 AND will Donald Trump be elected to be US President in 2024?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
For the AI Sputnik moment: There is said to be an "AI Sputnik moment" if ANY of the following come true before 2050,
A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system. Upon the announcement, their stock price skyrockets by over 100% compared to its previous value within 7 days, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock price is likely a result of the AI development.
For the US Presidential election: This question will resolve as Yes for the person who wins the 2024 US presidential election, and No for all other options. This will be the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment.
This question is not limited to the individuals currently listed below; the question may resolve as No for all listed options, and options may be added later.
Resolves YES if both of these events happen. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
There is said to be an "AI Sputnik moment" if ANY of the following come true before 2050,
A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system. Upon the announcement, their stock price skyrockets by over 100% compared to its previous value within 7 days, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock price is likely a result of the AI development.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
From Wikipedia,
Sputnik 1 was the first artificial Earth satellite. It was launched into an elliptical low Earth orbit by the USSR on 4 October 1957 as part of the Soviet space program. It orbited for three weeks before its batteries died and then orbited silently for two months before it fell back into the atmosphere on the 4th January 1958.
[...]
The satellite's unanticipated success precipitated the American Sputnik crisis and triggered the Space Race, part of the Cold War. The launch was the beginning of a new era of political, military, technological and scientific developments.
Show More

Q.title: Who will be elected to be US President in 2024? (Donald Trump)
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the person who wins the 2024 US presidential election, and No for all other options. This will be the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment.
This question is not limited to the individuals currently listed below; the question may resolve as No for all listed options, and options may be added later.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
Joseph Robinette Biden Jr. is the incumbent US President after winning the 2020 election. He has stated multiple times his intention of running for re-election, particularly if the Republican nominee would be Donald Trump. A March 2022 poll by CNN found 52% of respondents expected Biden not to run for re-election, compared to 29% who predicted that he would.
The previous US President Donald Trump has expressed several hints of his desire to run for re-election, stopping short of officially filing his campaign.
The 2024 United States presidential election is scheduled for Tuesday, November 5, 2024.

reasons: An AI Sputnik moment could have significant geopolitical implications, potentially influencing global economic and political landscapes. The US President in 2024, especially if it is Donald Trump, might have a particular stance on AI development and regulation, which could affect or be affected by such a moment.
Donald Trump's policies and international relations stance could influence the global AI race, potentially accelerating or decelerating the occurrence of an AI Sputnik moment.
The AI Sputnik moment could lead to significant economic changes, which might impact the political climate and the 2024 US presidential election outcome.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as the US President's policies and stance on AI could influence or be influenced by an AI Sputnik moment.

P.title: Will most dark matter turn out to be primordial black holes?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if the scientific consensus (as defined in the fine print) at resolution date is that primordial black holes represent 50% or more of the mass contained in dark matter in the observable universe today.
This question resolves negatively if the consensus is that said figure is less than 50% or that dark matter does not exist.
Show More

Q.title: Will Mars have a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2100, either Mars or the Moon has a permanent population of at least 10,000 people. A 'permanent population' is defined as individuals who have resided on Mars or the Moon for a continuous period of at least 6 months, without returning to Earth. The count of 10,000 people must be maintained for a minimum of 30 consecutive days to account for transient fluctuations in population.

The population figures must be confirmed by at least two of the following authoritative sources: The United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs (UNOOSA), the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), the European Space Agency (ESA), or the respective space agencies of countries with active lunar or Martian colonies.

In the event that both Mars and the Moon reach the population threshold within the same Earth calendar month, the question will resolve as Yes for the body that reached the threshold first, according to the timestamps provided by the authoritative sources. If such timestamps are not available, the question will resolve as Yes for the body for which the population confirmation is published first by any of the authoritative sources.

Should neither Mars nor the Moon have a permanent population of 10,000 people by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No. In the case of a dispute or lack of clear data, the question will be resolved by a panel of experts from the International Astronautical Federation (IAF).

P_and_Q.title: Will most dark matter turn out to be primordial black holes AND will Mars have a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for dark matter:
This question resolves positively if the scientific consensus (as defined in the fine print) at resolution date is that primordial black holes represent 50% or more of the mass contained in dark matter in the observable universe today.
This question resolves negatively if the consensus is that said figure is less than 50% or that dark matter does not exist.

Resolution Criteria for Mars and Moon population:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2100, either Mars or the Moon has a permanent population of at least 10,000 people. A 'permanent population' is defined as individuals who have resided on Mars or the Moon for a continuous period of at least 6 months, without returning to Earth. The count of 10,000 people must be maintained for a minimum of 30 consecutive days to account for transient fluctuations in population.

The population figures must be confirmed by at least two of the following authoritative sources: The United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs (UNOOSA), the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), the European Space Agency (ESA), or the respective space agencies of countries with active lunar or Martian colonies.

In the event that both Mars and the Moon reach the population threshold within the same Earth calendar month, the question will resolve as Yes for the body that reached the threshold first, according to the timestamps provided by the authoritative sources. If such timestamps are not available, the question will resolve as Yes for the body for which the population confirmation is published first by any of the authoritative sources.

Should neither Mars nor the Moon have a permanent population of 10,000 people by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No. In the case of a dispute or lack of clear data, the question will be resolved by a panel of experts from the International Astronautical Federation (IAF).

P.title: Will most dark matter turn out to be primordial black holes?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if the scientific consensus (as defined in the fine print) at resolution date is that primordial black holes represent 50% or more of the mass contained in dark matter in the observable universe today.
This question resolves negatively if the consensus is that said figure is less than 50% or that dark matter does not exist.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
A primordial black hole (PBH) is
a hypothetical type of black hole that formed soon after the Big Bang...Since primordial black holes did not form from stellar gravitational collapse, their masses can be far below stellar mass.
As of this writing, no direct observational evidence of PBHs exists.
Dark matter is
a form of matter thought to account for approximately 85% of the matter in the universe...Its presence is implied in a variety of astrophysical observations, including gravitational effects that cannot be explained by accepted theories of gravity unless more matter is present than can be seen.
It has been suggested () that PBHs are a natural candidate for dark matter. Although astrophysical measurements and theoretical arguments have put severe constraints (, Figure 3) on the possibility that PBHs constitute a significant fraction of dark matter across most of the PBH mass range. However, the "asteroid mass region" between
10
14
-
10
19
kg has not been ruled out yet, although this may merely "reflect the difficulty of detecting such light compact objects" (, Section IV).
Show More

Q.title: Will Mars have a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2100, either Mars or the Moon has a permanent population of at least 10,000 people. A 'permanent population' is defined as individuals who have resided on Mars or the Moon for a continuous period of at least 6 months, without returning to Earth. The count of 10,000 people must be maintained for a minimum of 30 consecutive days to account for transient fluctuations in population.

The population figures must be confirmed by at least two of the following authoritative sources: The United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs (UNOOSA), the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), the European Space Agency (ESA), or the respective space agencies of countries with active lunar or Martian colonies.

In the event that both Mars and the Moon reach the population threshold within the same Earth calendar month, the question will resolve as Yes for the body that reached the threshold first, according to the timestamps provided by the authoritative sources. If such timestamps are not available, the question will resolve as Yes for the body for which the population confirmation is published first by any of the authoritative sources.

Should neither Mars nor the Moon have a permanent population of 10,000 people by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No. In the case of a dispute or lack of clear data, the question will be resolved by a panel of experts from the International Astronautical Federation (IAF).

reasons: The discovery that most dark matter is composed of primordial black holes could have significant implications for our understanding of the universe, which might influence space exploration priorities and funding.

If primordial black holes are a major component of dark matter, it could affect the safety and feasibility of long-term space colonization efforts, potentially influencing where and how we establish large permanent populations in space.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, particularly in the context of space exploration and colonization.
